courses.subject: DOTE
courses.title: Managing Business Data in Excel and Tableau
courses.description: This course will introduce fundamental business data management skills and business intelligence tools that are essential for business management. The course will help students to develop basic concepts of data collection and handling, and to know how to structure and solve business problems using Microsoft Excel and Tableau, the most popular and penetrated tool, with the support of Office 365 for Cloud-based communication. Topics such as Storytelling with Tableau, SharePoint, Formulas and Functions, Charts, Subtotals, PivotTables, PivotCharts, What-If Analysis, Specialized Functions, Statistical Functions, Multiple-Sheet Workbook Management, XML, Power Add-Ins, Workbook Distribution, Templates, Styles, and Macros will be covered.

courses.subject: DOTE
courses.title: Basic Quantitative Methods for Hospitality and Real Estate
courses.description: This course introduces statistical and operation methods appropriate to the hospitality and real estate industry, which include descriptive statistics, probability, correlation and regression, forecasting, decision analysis, quality control, and hotel yield management. Each method will be discussed using examples related to the hospitality and real estate industry.

courses.subject: DOTE
courses.title: Economics for Business Studies I
courses.description: This course is a general introduction to the theory of price in a market economy. Topics include basic economic concepts, the theory of demand, production and cost, the operation of firms in competitive, oligopolistic and monopolistic markets, costs and benefits of government intervention in market economy, and introduction to game theory and informational economics. Analytical approach is used whenever appropriate. Applications on practical business problems are emphasized.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Not for students who have taken ECON2011 or ECON3011.

courses.subject: DOTE
courses.title: Basic Economics for the Hospitality and Tourism Industry
courses.description: This course is to provide the students with a basic understanding of the economics of the firm as well as macro-economics. The market forces of demand and supply as well as the firm's price and output decision under various forms of market structure will be analysed. In addition, national income, international trade theory, commercial policies, and foreign exchange market will be treated briefly. Economic applications that are particularly relevant to the hospitality industry will be emphasized.

courses.subject: DOTE
courses.title: Fundamentals of Business Economics
courses.description: This course intends to provide students with fundamentals to the understandings of both micro- and macro-economics for business decision makings and applications. Topics of microeconomics include demand and supply and elasticities, market structure and monopoly power, and the government and its economic functions. Topics of macroeconomics include unemployment, inflation, GDP and long term growth issues, aggregate supply and demand, and fiscal and monetary policies. Other topics of interests can also be included by the course instructor.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Not for students who have taken DSME1030/DOTE1030, DSME1040/DOTE1040 and equivalent courses offered by other departments.

courses.subject: DOTE
courses.title: Economics for Business Studies II
courses.description: This course is a general introduction to the theory of the determination of national income and aggregate economic behaviour. Topics include national income accounting, unemployment, inflation, monetary and fiscal policies for economic stabilization, and international economic issues. Applications of basic macroeconomic principles to contemporary business issues are emphasized.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Not for students who have taken ECON2021 or ECON3021 or UGEC2015

courses.subject: DOTE
courses.title: Statistical Analysis for Business Decisions

meetings.location: Chung Chi College Lib CK TSE
Chung Chi College Lib CK TSE
Chung Chi College Lib CK TSE

courses.description: This course deals with the fundamentals of statistical methods, including descriptive statistics, probability, statistical inference, simple linear regression and basic ANOVA. Application of statistical methods to problems pertaining to business will be emphasized throughout this course.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Not for students who have taken ECON2121 or FINA2220 or PSYC2010 or SEEM2430 or STAT2103 or UGEB2471

courses.subject: DOTE
courses.title: Applied Econometrics for Business Decisions
courses.description: This course introduces to students selected topics in applied statistics which are useful to business decisions and research. Regression analysis is stressed. Topics include linear regression models, some special topics in regression analysis and two-factor analysis of variance (ANOVA). Applications to business and economic problems will be emphasized throughout this course.
courses.enrollment_requirement: 1. Prerequisite: DSME2011/DOTE2011 or FINA2220. 2. Not for students who have takenECON2121.

courses.subject: DOTE
courses.title: Operations Management

meetings.location: Fung King Hey Bldg Swire Hall1
Fung King Hey Bldg Swire Hall1

courses.description: The objective of this course is to provide students with an understanding of how the design, operation, and control of production/operation systems can most effectively produce and/or deliver goods and services to meet customers' needs. Students will be exposed to the problems and issues confronting operations managers in the business world today. Students will also be provided with the language, concepts, insights and tools to address operations management issues. How companies can gain competitive advantage through operations will be discussed. This course will emphasize applications rather than theories. However, the underlying logic of the concepts will be examined so that students can understand the principles upon which their approach is based.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Prerequisite: HTMG1010 or MGNT1010 or 1020.

courses.subject: DOTE
courses.title: Business Analytics
courses.description: This course will provide a basis for handling and analyzing business data. This course will also give a chance to learn R which is rapidly becoming the default analytics platform as it supports diverse set of analytic tools and statistical methods. This course will present students with real datasets and give opportunities of ‘learning by doing’ through hands-on experience. Specifically, we will study basic concepts in business analytics, and techniques and skills related to data exploration, data utilities, conducting statistical tests, data mining and modeling.

courses.subject: DOTE
courses.title: Business Information Systems
courses.description: This course aims to survey information system technology with an emphasis on the development of computer-based information systems (CBIS). Major topics include: impact of CBIS on management, elements of system development life cycle, data management, transaction processing system, decision support systems, expert systems, and information resources management, etc. Important issues in e-Business such as information technology, security, marketing, finance, and multi-national trade, and practical operation will be discussed.
courses.enrollment_requirement: 1. Prerequisite: ACCT1111 or 2111 or HTMG1010 or MGNT1010 or 1020. 2. Not for students who have taken SEEM3490.

courses.subject: DOTE
courses.title: Current Topics in Business Economics
courses.description: This course provides students with an opportunity to further their knowledge in selected areas of business economics. Topics and issues of current and emerging interest are discussed and explored. Throughout this course, student initiative and participation in discussion and projects related to the selected topics will be emphasized.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Prerequisite: DSME1030/DOTE1030 or DSME1040/DOTE1040

courses.subject: DOTE
courses.title: Artificial Intelligence Empowered Business

meetings.location: Lee Shau Kee Archi Bldg G04
Lee Shau Kee Archi Bldg G04
Lee Shau Kee Archi Bldg G04

courses.description: In today’s fast-evolving digital landscape, artificial intelligence (AI) is transforming how businesses operate, innovate, and compete. This course provides business undergraduate students with a comprehensive understanding of AI concepts, tools and applications in the business world. Through case studies, hands-on projects and interactive discussions, students will explore topics such as machine learning, data-driven decision-making, AI ethics and industry-specific applications. By the end of the course, students will be equipped with the knowledge and skills to leverage AI for strategic advantage and drive innovation in their future careers.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Prerequisite: DOTE1021 or DOTE2011 or ECON2121 or FINA2230 or STAT2001 or permission from instructor

courses.subject: DOTE
courses.title: Behavioral Economics and Business Decisions
courses.description: Building on booming evidence in psychology and economics suggesting that individuals' behaviors deviate from the standard economic theory systematically, behavioral economics becomes a fast growing field. In this course, we will provide a broad overview of the modern advances in behavioral economics and the insights gained from incorporating psychology into economic modeling to understand how the psychological factors affect individuals' decision making, and show the business implications of those psychologically richer models, specifically on the strategies of areas including but not limited to consumer decision, investment and competition strategy of the firm, pricing practice, management decision, marketing and advertising, finance and insurance market.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Pre-requisite: DSME1030/DOTE1030 or equivalent course

courses.subject: DOTE
courses.title: Business Forecasting
courses.description: This course provides students with principles and methods in forecasting for managerial planning. Major topics include multiple regression analysis and time series analysis with emphasis on smoothing techniques, decomposition methods, Box-Jenkins procedures, and indicator forecasting. Applications of the methods to both short-term and long-term forecasting to business, industries and national business trends are also emphasized.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Prerequisites: DSME2011/DOTE2011 and DSME2021/DOTE2021.

courses.subject: DOTE
courses.title: Corporate Economics
courses.description: This course provides economic views on the operations of enterprises in a market environment for corporate decision-making and strategy formulation. Students will learn how to analyse market structure and performance, how firms seek competitive advantage, and how industries change. Emphasis will be on the application of economic principles to major business decisions, including pricing, product mix, market entry, mergers, and adoption of new technologies. Industrial policy and its implications will also be discussed.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Prerequisites: (a) DSME1030/DOTE1030 and DSME1040/DOTE1040 and (b) HTMG1010 or MGNT1020

courses.subject: DOTE
courses.title: Global Economics
courses.description: The purpose of this course is to equip business students with theory and knowledge of international economics. Both international trade and international macroeconomics will be covered. Applications, especially to current issues, will be emphasized throughout the course.Topics are categorized into three parts: international trade theory and policy, international macroeconomic theory and practice, and applications such as the impact of globalization, and the linked exchange rate in Hong Kong.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Prerequisite: DSME1030/DOTE1030 and DSME1040/DOTE1040.

courses.subject: DOTE
courses.title: Economic Aspects of Business Environment
courses.description: This course provides students with an economic perspective of the business environment and equips them with a solid grounding in business economics required for management studies at the university level. The major topics include: economic views of government and business; public choice and regulation; fiscal, monetary, trade and development policies; and the international environment. Examples will be drawn from Hong Kong, PRC in its economic reform since 1979 and the Asian NIE's competitive advantage and trade and industrial policy. Students are expected to exercise initiative in identifying aspects of special interest for in-depth reading. Empirical aspects of economic studies will be stressed through lecturing and case study.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Prerequisites: DSME1030/DOTE1030 and DSME1040/DOTE1040, or equivalent courses.

courses.subject: DOTE
courses.title: Macroeconomics for Managers
courses.description: This intermediate-level macroeconomics course is application-oriented and aimed at potential managers. Topics include contemporary aggregate demand and aggregate supply models; money and banking; fiscal and monetary policies on the macro economy and business environments; models of investments; real versus financial investments and evaluation; business cycle theory and sectorial forecasts; and the international linkage and different exchange rate systems. Managerial strategies to the changing business and macroeconomic environments will be emphasized.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Prerequisites: DSME1030/DOTE1030 and DSME1040/DOTE1040, or equivalent courses.

courses.subject: DOTE
courses.title: Game Theory for Business Strategy
courses.description: This course aims to develop a game theoretic framework for understanding strategies in business. When making managerial decisions, managers must take into account the reactions of rival firms, governments and their subordinates. Game theory offers a systematic way to analyze strategic decision-making process in business, including competition in oligopoly market, contract design, strategic use of information, auction and bargaining.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Prerequisite: DSME1030/DOTE1030

courses.subject: DOTE
courses.title: Decision Modeling and Analytics
courses.description: This course introduces the concepts and methods of decision making and analysis, which involves the application of mathematical modeling and analysis to business problems. Models are simplified representations of real situations and can be invaluable tools in decision making. Students will learn the basic elements of modeling-how to formulate a model and how to use and interpret the information a model produces. The emphasis is on models that are widely used in diverse industries and functional areas, including finance, operations, and marketing. Applications include production planning, revenue management, sales force planning, risk management, portfolio optimization, among others. We use spreadsheets and other tools to implement, solve, and analyze the models we develop.

courses.subject: DOTE
courses.title: Web Analytics
courses.description: The course focuses on the collection, analysis, and reporting of Internet data for purposes of optimizing web usage and enhancing business decisions. Both online and offline web analytics tools are used for measuring and analyzing web traffic, website performance, and visitor behavior in online commercial settings. Topics covered include web analytics concepts, web analytics technologies and techniques, visitor activity analysis methods, and web intelligence fundamentals.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Pre-requisite: DSME2011/DOTE2011 and DSME2021/DOTE2021 or permission of instructor.

courses.subject: DOTE
courses.title: Managerial Economics in the Information Age
courses.description: Managerial Economics combines economic theory and managerial practice, and it is the economic foundation of business analysis and strategy. This course focuses on the application of economic theories and tools to real world management problems and business challenges. Drawing on decision theory, game theory, models of markets and quantitative techniques, the course will apply fundamental concepts of economics to various business decisions, such as demand analysis, production and cost, pricing practices, capital budgeting and risk analysis. Particular attention will be paid to new industries in the information age.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Prerequisites: DSME1030/DOTE1030 and DSME1040/DOTE1040.

courses.subject: DOTE
courses.title: Data Management and Big Data Analytics
courses.description: This course focuses on (1) business data requirement analysis, modeling and management; and (2) big data crawling, management system and analytics. The main theme is to capture business applications and requirements, turn them into data models and manage the data using modern database systems. We will also examine methods for capturing, organizing and manipulating big data. Topics such as data integration, big data, DBMS, SQL, Relational model, Entity Relationship model, Data Warehousing, MongoDB, NoSQL and Map/Reduce are covered.

courses.subject: DOTE
courses.title: Guided Research in Business Economics
courses.description: The course allows students to investigate in depth a topic of business economics issues under close direction of a teacher. The topics include important macroeconomic issues and policies related to business operation, economy industry analysis, corporate strategies and trend forecasting in a particular industry, and governmental industrial policies and regulations. The course also covers essential skills in research, report writing and presentation.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Prerequisites: DSME1030/DOTE1030 and DSME1040/DOTE1040.

courses.subject: DOTE
courses.title: Economic Analytics

meetings.location: Lee Shau Kee Archi Bldg G04

courses.description: This course aims to provide economic views on the operations of enterprises for understanding corporate decision making and strategy formulation. The course is linked to game theory, the theory of the firm and industrial organization, and information economics. In particular, emphasis will be placed on the application of economic principles to major business decisions, including pricing, market entry and exit, strategic use of information and contract design. Industry analysis and governmental regulation will also be discussed.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Prerequisite: DSME1030/DOTE1030

courses.subject: DOTE
courses.title: Selected Topics of Decisions, Operations and Technology
courses.description: This course is designed to investigate and to discuss selected topics of current interests in the area of business/managerial economic and/or decision science analysis.

courses.subject: DOTE
courses.title: Information Systems Analysis and Design
courses.description: This course aims to introduce to students various activities associated with the development of business information systems. Students will learn to analyse information requirements and to design appropriate solutions that lead to sophisticated business systems. The concepts of system development life cycle (SDLC) and human- computer interaction will be introduced. Various methodologies, such as structured- and object-oriented analysis and design, will be emphasized. An introduction on how to use a CASE tool to help developing business information systems will also be given.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Prerequisite: DSME2051/DOTE2051 or permission of instructor.

courses.subject: DOTE
courses.title: Data Communications and Networking
courses.description: This course introduces data communications concepts, components, architecture, protocols, and standards for message movement within a network. Both the technical and managerial aspects of designing, controlling, and managing networks in the distributed environment will be emphasized.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Prerequisite: DSME2051/DOTE2051 or permission of instructor.

courses.subject: DOTE
courses.title: Financial Information Technology
courses.description: This course examines the use of information technology and systems in financial services and investment management. Topics covered include neural network, fuzzy logic, data mining and decision technologies relevant to financial services. Students will also learn to use Excel VBA to develop financial application systems.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Prerequisite: DSME2051/DOTE2051 or permission of instructor.

courses.subject: DOTE
courses.title: Global Logistics Management
courses.description: This course will examine the integrative role of logistics within the supply chain and look at logistics services from the perspective of logistic service providers. The general concepts and importance of global logistics management will be a major focus. We will provide students with an overall understanding of various activities handled by logistic service providers. Through problem-solving scenarios, projects and case studies, we will cover concepts, practical tools, and effective practices in logistics management. Topics include: introduction to the logistics functions and logistics industries, distribution strategies, warehousing and transportation management, design of the logistics networks, purchasing and outsourcing, and logistics information systems.

courses.subject: DOTE
courses.title: Global Supply Chain Management
courses.description: This course will examine the strategic role of supply chain management in global competition. We provide students with the concepts, decision models and practical tools necessary for effective decision-making in the various areas of supply chain. Through problem solving and case studies, the course will develop students’ intuition behind many key supply chain concepts and practices. We will demonstrate how cost reduction, productivity improvement, flexibility, speed, and customer satisfaction can be achieved through supply chain enhancement. Topics include: the strategic framework for supply chain management, planning the demand and supply in a supply chain, planning and managing inventories in a supply chain, information technology management and information sharing in a supply chain, strategic alliances and coordination.

courses.subject: DOTE
courses.title: Business Web Design and Authoring
courses.description: This course provides students with the basic knowledge required for designing and developing state-of-the-art interactive sites in the WWW. The primary focus will be on using Java Applets and JSP Web server pages to create Web business applications that can handle user requests and activate the relevant business processes. As the power of Web business applications relies heavily on access to the content of available databases, this course will also explore the technologies that have gained wide attention in the business information technology sectors, such as Java Database Connectivity (JDBC) and the Extensible Markup Language (XML). No prior programming knowledge is required.

courses.subject: DOTE
courses.title: Data Mining for Business Intelligence
courses.description: This course will focus on data analysis and decision making in organization and across organizational boundaries. Learn how to use Business Intelligence (BI) tools to produce the valuable information to decision makers in the organization. This course will also introduce the fundamental data mining techniques (e.g. classification, clustering, market basket). Student will learn how to capture the right knowledge, providing it to the right user at the right time.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Pre-requisite: DSME2011/DOTE2011 and DSME2021/DOTE2021 or DSME2011/DOTE2011 and DSME2040/DOTE2040 or permission of instructor.

courses.subject: DOTE
courses.title: Information Systems Practicum
courses.description: This course bridges the gap between classroom and real world. It requires students to complete a real-world information systems project, in collaboration with a company or organization. A minimum of three and a maximum of five students are required to form a project team, under the joint supervision of a MIS faculty member and a senior executive of the sponsoring company.

courses.subject: DOTE
courses.title: Supply Chain and Logistics Analytics
courses.description: This course first reviews the fundamentals of supply chain management and logistics management, and then examines how business analytics can be used to improve the competitiveness of supply chains and logistics processes. We will discuss the strategic role of supply chain management in global competition and the effective decision-making in the various areas of supply chain. The integrative role of logistics within the supply chain and the many logistics issues confronting logistic service providers will be examined. We will explore applying such analytics as data mining, forecasting, and optimization on demand planning, supply chain planning, and logistics planning. Business analytics can be used to predict and diagnose managerial problems in supply chain and logistics management, tracking most profitable products, identifying product quality issues, and better forecasting raw material needs.

courses.subject: DOTE
courses.title: Business Process Analytics
courses.description: This course aims to enhance the knowledge and skills related to business process management and improvement, with an emphasis on the applications of analysis and simulation tools. A simulation package will be introduced and will be used to evaluate business process performance and identify possibility of process improvement. The knowledge learnt from the course can help improve scientific competence to deal with practical problems in various settings related to business process management.

courses.subject: DOTE
courses.title: Current and Regional Issues in Supply Chain and Logistics Management
courses.description: This course provides an overview of the current issues in supply chain and logistics management that are of special relevance to Hong Kong and mainland China. Hong Kong, a gateway (for Pearl River Delta) and a transshipment hub (for mainland China and other parts of Asia), houses many local and international logistics service providers. In this course, we examine the regional logistics industries that are of special relevance to Hong Kong and mainland China, as well as their principal agents. These agents include freight forwarders, warehousing operators, airlines, terminal operators, integrators, trucking operators, customs and electronic agents, etc. We will discuss the respective roles of these agents in the management of logistics within a supply chain. Recent trends in trade, distribution, and adoption of IT for cargo logistics are covered.

courses.subject: DOTE
courses.title: Network and Security
courses.description: This course is a survey of the concepts and principles of data communications and networks. It also provides an introduction to the field of information security, covering its management, technology, and practice. Topics include transmission and media, network and security protocols, network security and management, cryptography, and access control.

courses.subject: DOTE
courses.title: Microeconomic Theory
courses.description: This course is on advanced microeconomic theory. Topics include individual decision theory (consumer theory, production theory, choice under uncertainty), game theory (static and dynamic games under complete and incomplete information), and equilibrium and market failure (general equilibrium, principal-agent problems, economics of information, auctions, bargaining, and market design).
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MPhil-PhD Accountancy; or MPhil-PhD Business Administration; or MPhil-PhD Decision Sciences & Managerial Economics; or MPhil-PhD Decisions, Operations and Technology; or MPhil-PhD Finance; or MPhil-PhD Marketing

courses.subject: DOTE
courses.title: Macroeconomics in a Globalized Era
courses.description: The course begins by constructing a simplified model of the macro economy. This is intended to help organize your discussion of issues confronting an economy. Every opportunity is taken to reinforce the economic concepts with current data, particularly for the U.S. and China. We then proceed to examine the policy instruments used to steer an economy towards the objectives of sustainable growth, stable inflation and low unemployment. Broadly speaking, these policy tools are monetary policy, implemented by a country's central bank, and fiscal policy implemented by the government when it makes expenditure and taxation decisions. We extend our exposition of traditional monetary policy to explain the Federal Reserve's quantitative easing, as well as the essential factors contributing to the financial crisis which necessitated this unconventional monetary policy. We then move onto the interactions between economies as captured in their respective balance of payment accounts and exchange rate movements. Fluctuations in China's RMB will be closely analyzed at this point and open the door for an in-depth look into China's domestic imbalances. We also examine Hong Kong's unique currency board system under-pinning our linked exchange rate.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in EMBA

courses.subject: DOTE
courses.title: Macroeconomics for Business Executives
courses.description: This course provides students with a basic understanding of the state of the global economy and macroeconomic policy. Topics include national income accounting, unemployment, inflation, monetary and fiscal policies, and international economic interactions. Applications of economic theories to current macroeconomic phenomena will be emphasized.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MBA; or JD/MBA Double Degree Programme

courses.subject: DOTE
courses.title: Business Analytics
courses.description: The major objective of this course is to provide students with real life examples of the application of quantitative methods, such as business statistics and operations research, to help business executives solve problems in competitive business environments.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in EMBA; or EMBA (Chinese)

courses.subject: DOTE
courses.title: Strategic Value of Innovation and Technology
courses.description: As an organization gets bigger and more mature, there is a tendency to soften up on the original entrepreneurial and innovative culture. In the digital economy, competitors are coming from not just the same industry but also innovative tech giants and start-ups. The need for faster change and continued growth can only be met with increased flexibility, agility and innovation. Corporate leaders need to think and act like entrepreneurs to stay relevant and competitive in the Digital Economy. Fortunately, innovation and entrepreneurship are not just for tech giants and start-ups. They can be learned. This course is designed for business leaders and professionals to acquire an even greater level of entrepreneurial, innovative and agile mindset and capabilities as the ultimate source of competitive advantage.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in EMBA

courses.subject: DOTE
courses.title: Statistical Analysis
courses.description: This course is intended to equip students with the basic statistical tools required for the quantitative analysis of business problems. Topics include basic sampling and analysis of data, probability distribution functions, estimation of parameters and hypothesis testing, goodness-of-fit tests, analysis of variance, simple regression, correlation, and basic non-parametric statistical methods.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MBA; or JD/MBA Double Degree Programme; or MSc Business Analytics; or MSc in Management of Real Estate and Hospitality Assets; or MSc Information & Technology Management; or MSc in Real Estate; or MSc in Info Sci and Tech Mgt

courses.subject: DOTE
courses.title: Econometric Theory and Applications
courses.description: This course is designed for business Ph.D. students who need to apply econometrics in their research. The major contents of this course will focus on two parts. The first part will cover fundamental econometrics topics such as ordinary least squares, instrumental variable estimation, panel data models, and generalized linear model. The second part will cover topics about business causal inference by either randomized field/lab experiments or natural experiments such as matching, difference-in-differences, and regression discontinuity design. This course is a graduate econometrics course that emphasizes application in pratice. Knowledge of multivariate calculus, linear algebra, statistics, and econometrics at the undergraduate level is preferred.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MPhil-PhD Accountancy; or MPhil-PhD Business Administration; or MPhil-PhD Decision Sciences & Managerial Economics; or MPhil-PhD Decisions, Operations and Technology; or MPhil-PhD Finance; or MPhil-PhD Marketing

courses.subject: DOTE
courses.title: Strategic Information Systems
courses.description: This course discusses the role of information technology (IT) in corporate strategy, along with its strategic, organizational, and technical issues in management and use. Topics include IT and business strategy alignment, IT-enabled business process reengineering, IT outsourcing, information systems planning and management, e-commerce technology and management, as well as business intelligence and analytics. Emphasis of the course is on how IT can contribute to organizational effectiveness.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MSc Information & Technology Management; or EMBA (Chinese); or MSc Business Analytics; or MSc in Info Sci and Tech Mgt

courses.subject: DOTE
courses.title: Global Supply Chain Management
courses.description: This course introduces global supply chains and logistics management topics including the concepts, insights, practical tools, and decision support systems for the effective management of global supply chains. This course will convey both the intuitions behind many key supply chain and logistics management concepts and provide simple techniques that can be used to analyze various aspects of the global supply chain and logistics management.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MSc in Management

courses.subject: DOTE
courses.title: Operations Management
courses.description: Efficient and effective operations enable firms to gain a competitive advantage by creating cost leadership, quality superiority, and capability of meeting customer demands quickly. This course will introduce concepts, issues, tools, and techniques in designing, managing and improving business processes. Topics encompass: operations strategy, process analysis, quality management, and supply chain management, etc. Cases and business best practices will be discussed in the course to demonstrate that companies can use (and have used) the principles from this course to significantly enhance their competitiveness.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MBA; or JD/MBA Double Degree Programme; or EMBA

courses.subject: DOTE
courses.title: Operations and Supply Chains Strategies
courses.description: Efficiency and effectiveness of operations and supply chains provide significant contributions to a firm's competitive advantage. This course will focus on strategic aspects of managing operations and supply chain processes that enable a firm to match its supply with the demand for its goods and services. The course will discuss concepts, techniques and strategies for managing process capacity and flexibility, demand and supply variability, and supply chain integration. It will also explore the challenges and opportunities offered by increasingly complex global supply chains for firms in the greater China region. Cases and business best practices will be discussed in the course to demonstrate that companies can use (and have used) the principles from this course to significantly enhance their competitiveness.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in EMBA; or EMBA (Chinese)

courses.subject: DOTE
courses.title: Quantitative Analysis for Decision Making
courses.description: The objective of this course is to introduce some of the most popular quantitative methods used in analysing business problems to students with no or only limited prior knowledge in this area. The course emphasizes the importance of decision making based on data. The lectures focus primarily upon understanding basic concepts about data analysis and statistical inferences and topics covered include descriptive statistics, probability, inferential statistics, and regression analysis. To free students from the trouble of learning and memorizing technical details of the analytical methods, computer software will be used extensively to perform the analysis so that the focus can be placed on understanding, interpreting, and communicating of the analytical results in a variety of business contexts.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MSc in Management

courses.subject: DOTE
courses.title: AI and Big Data Strategies
courses.description: The course brings insight and expertise to leveraging artificial intelligence and big data in business so students can harness the power of analytics and gain a true business advantage. Based on a practical framework with supporting methodology and hands-on exercises, this course helps identify where and how AI and big data can help entrepreneurs transform their businesses. Students will learn how to exploit new sources of customer, product, and operational data, coupled with advanced analytics and data science, to optimize key processes, uncover monetization opportunities, and create new sources of competitive differentiation.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in EMBA (Chinese)

courses.subject: DOTE
courses.title: Managerial Economics
courses.description: In this course economic analysis is applied to the management decision-making process. Topics to be treated include management decision-making under different situations, demand measurement and forecasting, production and cost, pricing, and capital budgeting. The course consists of lectures, exercises and discussions, and student group presentations of assigned problems and cases.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MBA; or JD/MBA Double Degree Programme; or EMBA (Chinese)

courses.subject: DOTE
courses.title: Business Analytics and Digital Innovation
courses.description: This course will explore how business data and big data play a key role in business model, service as well as process innovations. The unique ramifications of mastering the technical and managerial aspects of business analytics that lead to digital innovations will be discussed. The course will not only survey the latest enabling technologies and their applications in business management but also provide a holistic overview of the data analytics models and tools. Emphases are placed on understanding of intuitions behind these tools as well as their applications in various areas of management, including marketing, finance and operations.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MSc in Management

courses.subject: DOTE
courses.title: Managing Service Operations
courses.description: This course is designed for students to learn the latest theories, frameworks, concepts, techniques and to apply them in meeting the special challenges of managing service operations. The focus is to develop analytical thinking skills that will enable students contemplating careers in services to develop, evaluate and implement strategies for a wide range of service producing organizations. Topics will include: 1). the importance and economics of customer loyalty and approaches to build customer loyalty; 2). formulation and implementation of service strategies and the strategic service vision for greater business success; 3). management of the operational behavior of customers in service delivery; 4). design of sustainable service models that successfully incorporate a customer’s operating role; 5). analyses of customer data to inform managerial decision making; and 6). management of changes in service settings.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MSc Information & Technology Management; or MSc Business Analytics

courses.subject: DOTE
courses.title: Supply Chain Sustainability Management
courses.description: This course explores the design and management of environmentally and socially responsible supply chains. Governments, businesses, organizations, and consumers are increasingly aware of the importance of sustainability. We will first cover some basic concepts and processes of supply chain management. We will then study how and why companies integrate environmental and social sustainability concerns in managing their operations and supply chains, from product design, sourcing, to production and logistics. The course will explore the trade-offs between profit/costs and sustainability in decision making processes. The role of technology and innovation in promoting sustainable practices will also be discussed. We will use a mix of cases to understand the factors that drive companies’ sustainability effort and identify the opportunities and potential challenges.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MSc in Sustainable Global Business

courses.subject: DOTE
courses.title: Financial Data Modeling and Analysis
courses.description: This course is designed to cover mathematical and statistical/econometric techniques to financial issues, i.e. regression, time-series methods, forecasting models and simulation in financial applications. It shows students how to apply such techniques in the context of finance. For example, discussion of a number of distributions pays special attention to heavy tail, skewness and other distribution features with regard to financial return analysis. Time-series analyses aim to explain the important influence of time-dependence in making economical predictions. Regression models cover CAPM as well as multifactor models to connote the cross-section relations among financial returns. GARCH and other volatility models introduce the related applications in risk management context. The course involves extensive use of real data examples and hands-on examples.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MBA in Finance (40087); or MBA in Finance (40324)

courses.subject: DOTE
courses.title: Macro and Micro Economics
courses.description: This course is to provide students with basic understanding of modern economics of the firm and of the economy as a whole. The market forces of demand and supply as well as the firm’s price and output decisions under various forms of market structure will be analysed. Issues related to regulation and competition on the market will be studied. At the macro level, topics such as national income and its determination, international trade theory and commercial policies, the foreign exchange market, and the balance of international payments will be discussed.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MBA in Finance (40087); or MBA in Finance (40324)

courses.subject: DOTE
courses.title: Statistics and Decisions

meetings.instructor: Professor HUANG Junfei,   Professor LEE Ching Chyi
Professor HUANG Junfei,   Professor LEE Ching Chyi
Professor HUANG Junfei,   Professor LEE Ching Chyi
Professor HUANG Junfei,   Professor LEE Ching Chyi
Professor HUANG Junfei,   Professor LEE Ching Chyi
Professor HUANG Junfei,   Professor LEE Ching Chyi
Professor HUANG Junfei,   Professor LEE Ching Chyi
Professor HUANG Junfei,   Professor LEE Ching Chyi

courses.description: This course introduces fundamental concepts and techniques for analysing risk and formulating sound decisions in uncertain environments. Approximately half of the course focuses on probability theory and decision analysis including decision trees, decision criteria, the value of information, and simulation techniques. The remainder of the course examines statistical methods for interpreting and analysing data including sampling concepts, regression analysis, and hypothesis testing. Applications include inventory management, demand analysis, lotteries and gambling, portfolio analysis, insurance, auctions, surveys and opinion polls, environmental contamination and failure analysis. The course emphasizes analytical techniques and concepts that are broadly applicable to business decisions.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in Executive Master of Professional Accountancy; or MBA in Finance

courses.subject: DOTE
courses.title: Modelling Methodology in Management Science
courses.description: This course introduces students to some basic issues in the design and completion of a research project in business and economics. These issues include the initial choice of a research problem, the use of quantitative vs. qualitative methods for undertaking that research, potential pitfalls that may be met along the way, and the presentation of results in a scholarly manuscript. Fundamental modelling methodologies will also be covered.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MPhil-PhD Decision Sciences & Managerial Economics or MPhil-PhD Decisions, Operations and Technology

courses.subject: DOTE
courses.title: Platform and Business Strategies
courses.description: Success in business needs strategies. The advances of information technology have given business strategies a new dimension: building computer-mediated networks to facilitate transactions over e-platforms. The examples include Amazon, Google, Spotify, iTunes, Alibaba, Uber, Airbnb, and many other B2B, B2C, and C2C platforms. The e-platform business has network effect following demand-side scale economies that sees the value of a product from the willingness-to-pay of customers. This creates new perspectives of business strategies on pricing, platform products, envelopment attacks, winner-takes-all effect, and cannibalization. This course discusses how to run a successful business with e-platforms.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MBA; or JD/MBA Double Degree Programme

courses.subject: DOTE
courses.title: Research Methods in Microeconomics
courses.description: This course is a combination of two separate mini-courses.In the first half of the course we take a microeconomic perspective to analyze a number of important resource-allocating systems that are widely used in real life, including auctions, matching mechanisms, and trading platforms for financial assets. For each system we study its objective, structure, and actual performance. We will focus on the theoretical aspects of these systems, but will also examine empirical findings on how well they function. The second half of course surveys modern methods of applied micro-econometric research. We will begin by reviewing the Rubin Causal Model, its relationship with structural models, and the econometric definition of identification. We will then proceed to consider a number of econometric estimators, research designs, and inferential methods.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MPhil/PhD Decision Sciences and Managerial Economics or MPhil-PhD Decisions, Operations and Technology

courses.subject: DOTE
courses.title: Data Visualization and Business Intelligence
courses.description: In the increasingly competitive world, the need for timely analysis of constantly expanding data to gain business intelligence and communication of the results to the key decision makers has become a vital part of a company’s operation. In the past, business intelligence used to be in the domain of IT specialists. With the advent of self-service data visualization and business intelligence tools, such as Excel BI toolkit, now anyone with adequate training can produce their own analyses with minimal support from central IT. The aim of this course is to introduce to students the Excel BI toolkit that has become an integral part of Excel since Excel 2013. Designed to handle very large amount of data, the toolkit consists of four add-ins, namely, Power Query, Power Pivot, Power View, and Power Map. Students will learn how to use these add-ins to gain business intelligence. Students who are interested in taking this course are expected to have at least intermediate level and preferably advanced level of Excel skills.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MBA; or JD/MBA Double Degree Programme

courses.subject: DOTE
courses.title: Multivariate Statistics
courses.description: This course provides students with the basic multivariate analysis principles, techniques, and applications based on statistics theory. Major topics include factor analysis, multiple discriminant analysis, multivariate analysis of variance, cluster analysis, principle component analysis, etc. The techniques introduced will be useful in conducting quantitative research in various areas in business and economics including management, marketing, and management information system. Applications of the techniques to real – world economic and business problems will be emphasized. Statistical software will also be introduced to familiarize students with the application of multivariate analysis techniques in their research.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MPhil-PhD Decision Sciences & Managerial Economics; or MPhil-PhD Decisions, Operations and Technology

courses.subject: DOTE
courses.title: Economics of Information Systems
courses.description: The use of economics as a reference discipline for IS research has gained significant recognition over the past twenty years. This course is designed to introduce the research stream (as known as Economics of IS) to Ph.D. students with economic theories, models, and methodologies used in IS research. Specifically, this course deals with classical research questions, methods, and findings which form the backbone of Economics of IS. In addition, the course extends its focus and also covers the growing field of behavioral economics and its connection with IS research. Although the course relies primarily on IS literature, it is appropriate for Ph.D. students with a variety of backgrounds including Information Systems, Operations Management, Strategy, Marketing, and Economics.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MPhil-PhD Decision Sciences & Managerial Economics; or MPhil-PhD Decisions, Operations and Technology

courses.subject: DOTE
courses.title: Advanced BE Research Seminar
courses.description: This seminar course provides students with a broad exposure to research in Business Economics (BE). It will cover the development of current research topics such as game theory, information economics, firm and contract theory, industrial organization, and other topics related to microeconomics. Students are expected to read assigned papers thoroughly prior to classes and be able to discuss the paper's key assumptions and how those assumptions influence the paper;s key findings. The contribution of the papers to the literature will also be discussed.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MPhil-PhD Decision Sciences & Managerial Economics; or MPhil-PhD Decisions, Operations and Technology

courses.subject: DOTE
courses.title: Decision Models and Applications
courses.description: This course covers the principal quantitative techniques used in solving financial, marketing, and operations problems in the private and public sectors. Topics include decision under uncertainty, Markov chain, linear programming, classical optimization, dynamic programming, and integer programming.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MSc Information & Technology Management; or MSc Business Analytics

courses.subject: DOTE
courses.title: Advanced MIS Research Seminar
courses.description: This course provides students with a broad-based exposure to research in MIS and its research methodologies, including survey, case study, experimental design, and field work. Various theories used in MIS research will also be discussed to provide students with background on approaches to theory building and theory testing. Seminal MIS articles will be reviewed to orient students to the emergence of MIS discipline and its research tradition and trend.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MPhil-PhD Decision Sciences & Managerial Economics; or MPhil-PhD Decisions, Operations and Technology

courses.subject: DOTE
courses.title: Research Sem in Operations & SCM
courses.description: This seminar is designed to provide students with the latest knowledge on research issues, theories and methodologies in the areas of Operations and Supply Chain Management. Students will be required to read research papers, critique and synthesize other people's research work, and identify areas for future research. They are also required to present and discuss other people's research and their own research proposals. The instructor and scholars from different universities will also be invited to present their latest research. Topical areas will include Operations Supply Chain Strategy, Total Quality Management, Service Operations Management, Innovation and New Product Development, Lean Thinking, Business Process Improvement/Innovation, Relationship Management and Supply Chain Integration, Supply Chain/Logistics Network Design and other topics.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MPhil-PhD Decision Sciences & Managerial Economics; or MPhil-PhD Decisions, Operations and Technology

courses.subject: DOTE
courses.title: Artificial Intelligence for Business Research
courses.description: Modern artificial intelligence (AI) has largely reshaped our world over the past 10 years. This course is designed to prepare students from a broad range of business areas (e.g. Finance, Marketing, Accounting, Management, Operations, Information Systems, Business Economics, Hotel Management etc.) for the cutting-edge research that connects AI and business. At a high-level, students taking this course will learn the followings:• Fundamental concepts/methods of machine learning (ML) and AI that are used in business research ;• How business researchers have utilized ML/AI and what managerial questions have been addressed by ML/AI in the past several years ;• The huge mismatch between AI technologies and the adoption of AI technologies in our fields.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MPhil-PhD Accountancy; or MPhil-PhD Business Administration; or MPhil-PhD Decision Sciences & Managerial Economics; or MPhil-PhD Decisions, Operations and Technology; or MPhil-PhD Finance; or MPhil-PhD Marketing

courses.subject: DOTE
courses.title: Data Mining for Managers
courses.description: This course emphasizes on the applications of data mining techniques in business problems from managerial perspectives. Business applications such as customer relationship management and financial analysis will be discussed throughout the course. Some basic data mining techniques will also be explained for illustration purposes. They include clustering, market basket analysis, data warehouse, and neural networks.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For student in MSc Business Analytics

courses.subject: DOTE
courses.title: Economic Analytics
courses.description: This course is about applying economic models with data to deal with corporate decisions and strategies. The art and science of economic modeling for this purpose makes use of the principles and the tools derived from the studies of information economics, games, industrial organization and the related fields. The course is conducted in a variety of formats including lectures, cases studies and other activities. Operation and strategic issues covered in the course include setting prices, designing contracts, managing firm boundaries, controlling strategic information, analyzing entry and exit, and formulating competitive strategy.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MSc Business Analytics

courses.subject: DOTE
courses.title: Risk and Operations Analytics
courses.description: This course introduces the analysis of key issues related to the design and management of business operations using quantitative tools such as linear, integer, and non-linear programming, regression, and statistical analysis. It covers important topics such as revenue management and dynamic pricing, inventory theory, production control and scheduling, and risk management in supply chains, among others, and uses mathematical modeling, spreadsheet analysis, case studies, and simulation to deliver materials. The course introduces Monte Carlo simulations with Excel and Crystal Ball, focusing on their applications in solving business operations problems.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MSc Information & Technology Management; or MSc Business Analytics

courses.subject: DOTE
courses.title: Web Analytics and Intelligence
courses.description: The course focuses on the collection, analysis, and use of web data for business intelligence. Topics covered include web analytics concepts, web analytics technologies and techniques, visitor activity analysis methods, and web intelligence fundamentals. The course also evaluates practical, real-work analysis cases to demonstrate the strategic uses of web analytics for business intelligence and proper application of analytics techniques for online data optimization.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MSc Information & Technology Management; or MSc Business Analytics

courses.subject: DOTE
courses.title: Business Process Analysis and Simulation
courses.description: This course introduces knowledge used to model and analyze business processes, with an emphasis on quantitative skills. A simulation package will be introduced and will be utilized to evaluate business process performance and to facilitate the decision making on business process improvement. The knowledge learnt from the course can equip students with scientific competence and help them solve practical problems in various settings related to business process management.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MSc Information & Technology Management; or MSc Business Analytics

courses.subject: DOTE
courses.title: China in Global Economy
courses.description: This course is designed to help students understand the role of China in the Global Economy. We will review the reforms and the current state of the Chinese economy and its financial markets. Major topics such as the Belt and Road Initiative, The Bay Area, Sino-US trade war, China and ASEAN, Islamic Finance will be covered. We will also study the development of e-payment the green economy in China.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MBA; or JD/MBA Double Degree Programme

courses.subject: DOTE
courses.title: Selected Topics of Information and Technology Management
courses.description: This course is designed to investigate and to discuss selected topics of current interests in the area of information and technology management.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MSc Information & Technology Management; or MSc Business Analytics; or MBA; or JD/MBA Double Degree Programme; or MSc in Info Sci and Tech Mgt

courses.subject: DOTE
courses.title: Fintech and Transformation of Financial Services
courses.description: This course provides an introduction to FinTech such as blockchain, alternative lending, machine learning, and robo-advising. Students are expected to develop a broad understanding of the recent FinTech development and its impact in the financial industries. Students will also have hands-on and problem solving experiences that can be useful in FinTech applications and innovation. Topics may include but are not limited to: blockchain, bitcoins, smart contracts, decentralized applications, markets for smart contracts, alternative and P2P lending and crowdfunding, machine learning and its applications in FinTech such as robo-advising, AI and quantitative trading, legal issues in FinTech.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in EMBA (Chinese)

courses.subject: DOTE
courses.title: Fintech and Its Applications

meetings.location: Lee Shau Kee Archi Bldg G01
Lee Shau Kee Archi Bldg G01

courses.description: Advance in information technology has already started a revolution in the financial industry. Every part of the financial service system is affected, from daily payment to long-term investment, from efficiency gain to logic transformation. The pace of change is fast. Too fast to catch, yet too critical to miss. Institutions which can leverage the new technologies gain superior market insights, create new business models, and will become the future leaders of the financial service industry. Individuals who can understand and work with FinTech open new gates for investment and career development. This course introduces FinTech and examines opportunities and challenges. It seeks to equip students with both a deep and practical understanding of emerging technology in the FinTech arena as well as the necessary coding skills to tackle future demand. We are going to cover topics such as the fundamentals of the financial service system, technology disruption, data management and visualization, financial data mining (Python), quantitative trading and artificial intelligence, crowdfunding, blockchain technology, and RegTech.Applications on practical FinTech problems are emphasized with case discussions and programming assignments. While we will work with computer codes, this course does NOT assume any programming background from students.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MSc Information & Technology Management; or MSc Business Analytics; or MSc in Info Sci and Tech Mgt

courses.subject: DOTE
courses.title: Blockchain and Its Application
courses.description: Blockchain technology provides a dynamic shared ledger that enables peer-to-peer transfer of digital assets without any intermediaries, and is predicted to be a revolutionary technology that is just as impactful as the Internet. It is radically transforming financial services, supply chains, and other business services, as well as creating new opportunities for innovation. This course aims to provide students with basic knowledge of Blockchain and its practical applications in various business fields. It introduces the basic concepts and technologies of Blockchain with the technology’s initial application, the cryptocurrency Bitcoin. Students will then gain an understanding of the commercial, technical, and public policy fundamentals of Blockchain technology and smart contracts in both public and private applications. Finally, the class will discuss current and potential Blockchain applications in various business domains.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MSc Information & Technology Management; or MSc in Info Sci and Tech Mgt

courses.subject: DOTE
courses.title: Generative Artificial Intelligence for Business
courses.description: This course introduces generative artificial intelligence (AI) and its applications in business contexts. It covers key generative AI techniques, including deep learning, text generation, image generation, and other AI-driven solutions. The course also discusses opportunities for applying these techniques in business areas such as customer engagement, product design, and personalized marketing, as well as the associated challenges.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MSc Information & Technology Management; or MSc Business Analytics; or MSc in Info Sci and Tech Mgt

courses.subject: DOTE
courses.title: Advanced Information Systems Practicum
courses.description: This course bridges the gap between classroom and real world. It requires students to complete a real-world information systems project, in collaboration with a company or organization. Students are required to form a project team, under the joint supervision of a teacher and an executive of the sponsoring company.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MSc Information & Technology Management; or MSc in Info Sci and Tech Mgt

courses.subject: DOTE
courses.title: Data Communication and Networking
courses.description: This course discusses the concepts and principles of data communications and computer networks. It prepares students to make intelligent and informed decisions about moving voice, data, image and video between locations securely, by making them aware of the benefits, drawbacks, and effects related to various data communication technologies. Students will also learn how to make policy, design, and installation decisions related to planning and implementing data communication and network applications.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MSc in Information & Technology Management

courses.subject: DOTE
courses.title: Technology Startup-From Idea to Reality
courses.description: This is a practical course on entrepreneurial business management as a living skill to start, build and grow a technology enterprise. Learn by creating a new business based on the know-how and wisdom from Silicon Valley to Asia, including evaluating business opportunities, innovation, generating business model, business plan, team building, competition analysis, IP, financing, growth, Silicon Valley and Asian business culture.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MSc Information & Technology Management; or MSc Business Analytics

courses.subject: DOTE
courses.title: IT Law for Executives
courses.description: Information technology becomes more and more important in our business sector. Issues relating to information technology and law, such as privacy and location surveillance, digital signature, copyright, outsourcing, anti-competition and contracts are essential to our daily life. This course examines the link between IT law and business operations; it offers a clear picture to students who are at executive level with no related legal background. Topics will include introduction of the Hong Kong Legal System; Contract Law; Torts Law; internet impact on legal systems; IT and IP Laws in business operations and the latest Competition Ordinance.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MSc Information & Technology Management

courses.subject: DOTE
courses.title: Selected Topics of Business Analytics
courses.description: This course is designed to investigate and to discuss selected topics of current interests in the area of business analytics.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MSc Business Analytics; or MBA; or JD/MBA Double Degree Programme

courses.subject: DOTE
courses.title: Advanced Business Analytics Practicum
courses.description: This course bridges the gap between classroom and real world. It requires students to complete a real-world business analytics project, in collaboration with a company or organization. Students are required to form a project team, under the joint supervision of a teacher and an executive of the sponsoring company.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MSc Business Analytics

courses.subject: DOTE
courses.title: Data Visualization and Business Communication
courses.description: This course covers foundational perception principles, the art of designing impactful graphs, and strategies for clear, influential presentations. The course dives into the intricacies of effective data visualization and communication. The course invites some leading companies in different industries to share the skills they value in interviews and in work. Students are supposed to make presentations during classes.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MSc Business Analytics

courses.subject: DOTE
courses.title: Machine Learning for Business II
courses.description: As a second part of machine learning for business, this course provides a holistic overview of advanced machine learning and artificial intelligence models, as well as their mathematical and programming background. It covers, together with others, some commonly used machine learning and deep learning methods such as support vector machine, ensemble models, stacked generalization, and deep learning models. This course emphasizes understanding the intuition behind the methods and on applying them to business practices. It helps build hands-on experiences by using business data and Python, an analytics software package. Taking the first part and having certain coding knowledge will be needed for this course, and a decent familiarity with basic quantitative content (such as linear algebra, optimization, and probability/statistics) will also be required.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MSc Business Analytics; MSc Information & Technology Management; or MSc Information Science & Technology Management;Pre-requisite: DOTE6756

courses.subject: DOTE
courses.title: Business Forecasting
courses.description: This course provides students with principles and methods in forecasting for managerial planning. Major topics include multiple regression analysis, time series analysis with emphasis on smoothing techniques, decomposition methods, and Box-Jenkins procedures and indicator forecasting. Applications of the methods to both short-term and long-term forecasting to business, industries and national business trends are also emphasized.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MSc Business Analytics

courses.subject: DOTE
courses.title: Project Management
courses.description: This course covers the management of projects. A major focus is on how to manage various projects to successful completion within the constraints of resources and time. Included in the contents are the frameworks for proposal writing and planning, monitoring and controlling, and performance evaluation. Various project management techniques are covered including PERT/CPM and project appraisal. Case studies and field projects as well as lectures will be used as teaching methods.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MSc Information & Technology Management; or MSc Business Analytics; or MSc in Info Sci and Tech Mgt

courses.subject: DOTE
courses.title: Database and Big Data Management
courses.description: This course focuses on both business data and contemporary big data modeling and management. We will examine the different natures of data and big data, selection and representation as well as use of suitable methods and tools for storing and accessing them. Topics such as data integrity, DBMS, data warehousing, NoSQL and MapReduce are covered.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MSc Information & Technology Management; or MSc Business Analytics; or MBA; or JD/MBA Double Degree Programme; or MSc in Info Sci and Tech Mgt

courses.subject: DOTE
courses.title: Information Systems Analysis and Auditing
courses.description: This course provides students with knowledge and experience of analyzing the essential aspects of information systems in the real world. Emphases will be placed on the object-oriented analysis techniques using the Unified Modeling Language. Various key business activities will be discussed. This course will also explain the importance of business IS controls in contemporary IT governance. A business framework for the management of enterprise IS will be investigated.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MSc Information & Technology Management

courses.subject: DOTE
courses.title: Machine Learning for Business I

meetings.instructor: Professor JIN Qianran,   Professor ZHANG Renyu
Professor JIN Qianran,   Professor ZHANG Renyu
Professor JIN Qianran,   Professor ZHANG Renyu
Professor JIN Qianran,   Professor ZHANG Renyu
Professor JIN Qianran,   Professor ZHANG Renyu
Professor JIN Qianran,   Professor ZHANG Renyu
Professor JIN Qianran,   Professor ZHANG Renyu
Professor JIN Qianran,   Professor ZHANG Renyu

meetings.location: Lee Shau Kee Archi Bldg G03
meetings.instructor: Professor JIN Qianran,   Professor ZHANG Renyu

meetings.location: Lee Shau Kee Archi Bldg G03
meetings.instructor: Professor JIN Qianran,   Professor ZHANG Renyu

meetings.location: Lee Shau Kee Archi Bldg G03
meetings.instructor: Professor JIN Qianran,   Professor ZHANG Renyu

courses.description: This course aims to train students to extract patterns in vast amounts of data and discover actionable insights. It emphasizes the current issues, methodologies, practices, and emerging trends in machine learning. Students will learn key machine learning techniques to address existing business problems in today’s information-rich environments. Upon completing this course, students will build their analytical capabilities to use data for innovative business solutions. We will use Python as a language tool for machine learning during the course.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MSc Information & Technology Management; or MSc Business Analytics; or MSc in Info Sci and Tech Mgt

courses.subject: DOTE
courses.title: Mobile and Web Applications Development
courses.description: This course provides students with the basic knowledge to design and develop Android applications for mobile devices. Students will work directly with the Java programming language and the latest Android developer tools, with the goal of enabling students to produce fully functional prototypes independently. This course will also place some emphasis on developing web applications using JavaScript. The basic concepts of client server architecture and simple Java Server Pages (JSP) will also be introduced.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MSc in Information & Technology Management

courses.subject: DOTE
courses.title: Cyber Security
courses.description: This course provides an overview of the threats to networked organizations. Students will learn and understand the key issues associated with cyber space security, skills required to respond to security incidents, and knowledge needed to design security systems and protect security intrusions. Its coverage includes a variety of concepts and topics related to the securing of networked, cloud, and mobile processing environments.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MSc in Information & Technology Management

courses.subject: DOTE
courses.title: Technology Field Study
courses.description: This course consists of preparatory assignments in readings and a written study plan, followed by a five-day residential program to Silicon Valley, California or similar Science Parks in Asia. The course is concluded with a written report and an oral presentation. The goal in taking classroom sessions abroad is to expose our graduate students to a wide spectrum of issues related to IT business, which includes research and development, company culture, and ways to manage a technology company. The issues are highlighted through lectures or seminars by university professors, and visits to world class companies or research and development centres. Students will have chance to discuss with top executives from these companies. Through this course, students will be able to understand the strategies companies adopted, and solutions in tackling business issues.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MSc Information & Technology Management; or MSc Business Analytics

courses.subject: DOTE
courses.title: Supply Chain and Logistics Management
courses.description: This course covers the concepts, insights, practical tools, and decision support systems for the effective management of the supply chain. This course will convey both the intuitions behind many key supply chain and logistics management concepts and to provide simple techniques that can be used to analyze various aspects of the supply chain and logistics management. The role of supply chain and logistics management in the age of eBusiness will be addressed. Through readings and case studies, we will identify the current and prospective supply chain practices.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MSc Information & Technology Management; or MSc Busienss Analytics

courses.subject: DOTE
courses.title: Strategy and Innovation Management
courses.description: The aim of this course is to provide a solid grounding to students interested in managing various aspects of the innovation process and understanding it better from a policy perspective. The course is divided into two parts. Broadly, the first two-thirds of the course focuses more on analytic and strategic frameworks for managing innovation. This segment examines patterns of technological change and their impacts, planning for technological transitions, means for capturing economic benefits from innovation, and planning of innovation projects over time. The last third of the course examines more organizational issues involved in implementing strategies. These issues include management of teams and partnerships, learning within and across projects, the manager's role in forecasting and funding, directing and stopping innovation projects, technological entrepreneurship, and barriers to innovation. Case studies, both written and video-based, are used extensively to illustrate a range of technologies and the problems associated with developing them and bringing them to market.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in EMBA (Chinese)

courses.subject: DOTE
courses.title: Enterprise Resource Planning
courses.description: Enterprise Resource Planning (ERP) is an integrated information technology to manage company-wide business processes. The topics include two aspects: enterprise resource planning system and the ERP project implementation issues. This course will also introduce the evolution of ERP, concepts and applications of ERP. The topics of enterprise systems will mainly brief on the core modules along the value chain such as product development, order fulfillment, production and others. Finally, the "ERP and beyond" will address how the latest developments of ERP can be extended to fulfill the new demand of more enterprise initiatives. Students will be requested to work on a group project.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MSc Information & Technology Management; or MSc in Info Sci and Tech Mgt

courses.subject: DOTE
courses.title: Independent Study
courses.description: Students will be assigned a research project guided and supervised by a course instructor. The course aims to further develop students’ capability and experience in undertaking research study. Upon completion, students are required to submit and present their research report.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MPhil-PhD Decision Sciences & Managerial Economics or MPhil-PhD Decisions, Operations and Technology

courses.description: To monitor students’ progress in thesis and research.
